text: Chinatown MRT station is recognized as one of the busiest stations in Singapore and is a significant point of interest for tourists. It offers diverse dining options, from local eateries to vibrant street vendors. Visitors can easily explore nearby attractions such as Little India, Chinatown Complex, Chinatown Point, the Chinatown Street Market, and the Buddha Tooth Relic Temple, all within a short distance. Positioned at the intersection of Eu Tong Sen Street, New Bridge Road, and Upper Cross Street, this station provides essential rail connections to the bustling Chinatown district, where the harmonious blend of modern architecture and distinct Chinese cultural elements creates a unique urban landscape.

Chinatown Singapore.
This is a must visit location in Singapore especially during the Chinese New Year festival.
There are many stores popped up along the streets during the this period and in the evening the whole Chinatown will be so busy with the locals doing the usual New Year shopping.
It's so colorful and foods are on every street.
The wet market at basement of Chinatown complex is one of the busiest market in Singapore.
Many Dim Sum restaurant here in chinatown.
The tooth relic temple in Chinatown is the new landmark and you will never miss the temple when you are in Chinatown.

The Chinatown MRT Station is well located in the Hearts of Chinatown  with the triple link ways to People's Park Complex, People's Park Centre and Chinatown Point; a Shopping and Food Paradise.

Singapore's Chinatown is known as Niu che shui in Mandarin, Gu Chia Chwi in Hokkien and Ngau-che-shui in Cantonese - all of which mean "bullock water-cart" - and Kreta Ayer in Malay (Post-1972 spelling: "kereta air"), which means "water cart". This is due to the fact that Chinatown's water supply was principally transported by animal-driven carts in the 19th century. Although these names are sometimes used for referring to Chinatown in general, they actually refer to the area of Kreta Ayer Road.
